Award.AwardTitle: TRAVEL: Travel to Workshop on Behavioral Risk Modeling for Pandemic Prevention and Response

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a Travel Award to enable anthropologist Dr. James Holland Jones (Stanford University) and a post-doctoral scholar working with Dr. Jones to participate in a workshop on behavioral risk modeling for pandemic prevention and response. The workshop is hosted by the National Science and Technology Council and the Pandemic Prediction and Forecasting Science and Technology (PPFST) Working Group, at the National Museum of Natural History. The workshop will address the role of human behavior in pandemic prevention and response. Understanding human behavior and its consequences for disease transmission dynamics is essential for effectively developing a national pandemic preparedness plan.

Human behavior is central to many aspects of the ecology and evolution of emerging infectious disease (EEID). Consequently, the contributions of social scientists to work on EEID are essential. This workshop will provide an opportunity to better integrate behavioral and social sciences with EEID and pandemic preparedness. Dr. Jones brings to the workshop a unique constellation of expertise in the behavioral sciences, social structure, and the ecology and evolutionary biology of infectious disease.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Principal Investigator James Holland Jones, an anthropologist and disease ecologist at Stanford University, was invited to be a keynote speaker at the U.S. Pandemic Prediction and Forecasting Science and Technology (PPFST) working group meeting hosted by the Global Health Program of the Smithsonian Institution, on Oct. 22-23, 2018 at the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History (NMNH) in Washington, DC. Recent cuts to global health infrastructure meant that PPFST was unable to provide compensation for travel to the meeting and Jones had already spent his full travel allowance provided by Stanford for the year.


Jones sought funding for travel from the NSF/BCS program in cultural anthropology to defray the costs of travel and lodging for the meeting for himself and a post-doctoral fellow, Ashley Hazel. As a specialist in infectious disease and global health, attendance at this meeting represented an important component of Hazel's post-doctoral training.


At the meeting, Jones presented an opening keynote talk entitled, "Human Behavior and Pandemics: What We Don’t Know Might Hurt Us." In this talk, he detailed his recent work on the dimensions of human behavior that are important for understanding disease emergence and the potential transition from local outbreak to pandemic. The key take-aways from this talk include:

 

  • Infectious Diseases are Components of Complex Systems
  • Heterogeneity Drives Epidemics     
  • Mixing Affects Both Speed and Extent of Spread
  • Mobility at Multiple Scales Affects Both Speed and Extent of Spread
  • Behavior Change Makes Epidemic Modeling Difficult (But is Fundamentally Important)

The PPFST meeting proved an excellent opportunity for both Jones and Hazel to forge new professional connections. Jones was subsequently invited to give an online lecture on networks and the transmission dynamics of infectious disease for the PPFST's monthly video conference. Jones and Hazel have both consulted with Transmeta, an epidemic intelligence company, following interactions with the chief scientific officer at the Smithsonian meeting.
